US MARKET WRAP: Stocks jump in late trade
content:
EQUITIES: NDX +2% at 6897, SPX +1.61% at 2747, DJI +1.4% at 25311

Top sectors: Utilities +2.7%, Energy +2.2%, IT +2.2%

Bottom sectors: +0.8%, Telecom +0.8%, Consumer Staples +1%

The ES H8 contract was again in the 2700 to 2730 battleground (50d MA around 2730 in focus), remaining in positive territory throughout the course of the session, with utilities and staples doing a lot of the heavy lifting (all sectors were green). Late in the day, however, ES managed to find some impetus in quiet trade, rising out of that range towards session highs – with some chatter of a mini short squeeze – shaking-off the lethargy seen in recent afternoon trade. There wasn’t a specific narrative behind Friday’s equity gains, with many news outlets attributing the gains to Fed-related headlines, though that seems to be trying fit a narrative around the price action, rather than actually explaining the price action. Perhaps a more convincing explanation was the fall in US yields providing support (some models signal month-end Treasury buying). In stock specific news, HPE jumped after reporting earnings on Thursday, GIS was the laggard after announcing an $8bln deal to buy BUFF; in late trade, news that JWN family members were reportedly near finalising an offer to take the company private added a positive catalyst to equity trading. While stock trading has been choppy this week, ES finishes in the green (very slightly – and last week’s highs haven’t been meaningfully tested), though the range has been the narrowest in around six weeks.

 

TREASURIES: US T-Note futures settle 10 ticks higher at 120-23+

Month-end flows were seen supporting the Treasury Complex, and yields were lower across the curve. Some pointed out that index extensions this month are large, which may be contributing to Treasury buying. Some were also attributing Treasury gains to jittery stock markets, although that narrative is challenged by the equity price action, which has hardly screamed ‘panic’. The complex will likely take its next cue from Fed chair Powell’s testimony to Congress next week; fixed income traders will be looking for clues as to whether the Fed will raise its assessment of long-term rates, which could help the curve steepen.

 

FOREX: DXY finishes the week green

The DXY closes out the week in positive territory, though didn’t manage to stay above the 90.00 mark. On Friday the DXY was trading within a range (between c.89.80 to c.90.00, with unsustained breaches on both sides). Where the greenback goes from here will largely depend on the dual testimony of new Fed governor Powell before lawmakers (next Tuesday and Thursday). While analyst chatter is largely focussing on inflation, some are looking for clues as to whether the Fed will likely raise it’s longer-term view of where the Federal Funds Rate will peak in the cycle (a higher ‘peak’ rate will help a steepening of the curve, which may lend to dollar strength, the theory goes).

Other majors were also trading range-bound, unswayed by central bank speak from the Fed and ECB. GBP mostly looked through Brexit headlines (which again hint at difficulties in negotiations – next week’s Brexit speech from PM May is eyed, as well as EU’s Tusk coming to London). There was a mini flash crash in the pound that got some attention in pre-US trade (around 65 pips); although no convincing narrative has been put forward, thin liquidity around the 11am fix was cited, where 700mln GBP was put through on a single platform). Cable is flat just beneath 1.40, though trades with a positive bias vs the EUR (general weak EUR day).

 

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 78 cents higher at $63.55 per barrel; Brent futures settle 92 cents higher at $67.31 per barrel

Crude ends Friday on a firm footing, with CLc1 finishing green for the seventh straight session (according to Rtrs pricing, which differs slightly from daily settlement prices), capping another strong week for the crude complex (second week of gains). Today’s theme picks up from Thursday’s price action, where OPEC+ commentary was finally corroborated by weekly inventory data, though US production levels and export levels continued to be cautiously eyed by traders. There was further OPEC jawboning today, with Saudi’s energy minister once again arguing that oil markets were rebalancing, and he sees inventories continuing to fall through the course of 2018. Elsewhere, Libya’s El Feel oilfield (70k BPD) was shutdown, contributing to the bullish price action.

FX Weekly Wrap – big Central Bank focus amidst broad Usd comeback
content: A hectic week mainly dominated by Central Bank events along with some top tier data, while the Usd has staged a broad recovery with the DXY rebounding further from multi-year lows around 88.250 last week to 90.000+ at one stage?. RBA minutes did not offer any new policy clues, leaving Aud/Usd to back off further from 0.7900, especially after the more hawkish FOMC account of January’s policy meet that gave the Greenback the extra push to test chart resistance around 90.500-600. BoE testimony to the TSC essentially underlined the shift in guidance towards somewhat earlier tightening and by somewhat more than anticipated at the November QIR, but Cable struggled to clear 1.4000 (21DMA at 1.4007). ECB minutes reiterated growing confidence in the economic and inflation outlook, but also risks related to Eur strength that implies no change in guidance before March at the earliest, even though some members favoured dropping the easing bias – Eur/Usd hovering around 1.2300. Riksbank minutes were decidedly cautious/dovish and Eur/Sek spiked as a result, Krona extending losses made on weaker than forecast Swedish inflation data. Usd/Cad down sharply from Thursday’s post-weak Canadian retail sales highs (1.2773, fresh 2018 peak) with the immediate spike lower post-firm CPI unable to sustain a move further to the downside in the pair. Nzd undermined by cross buying through 1.0700 vs Aud and testing bids around 0.7300 vs the Usd after strong headline NZ retail sales data, but a less upbeat breakdown.

PREVIEW: Fed’s MPR to be released at 11:00 ET/16:00 GMT
content:
Ahead of Fed chair Powell’s dual-testimony before US lawmakers next week, the Fed’s Monetary Policy Report will be released at 11:00 ET on Friday 23 February. Key points to note:

INFLATION:

- Previously, the Fed had categorised inflation weakness as “transitory,” (in his November confirmation hearing, Powell himself alluded to uncertainty regarding the path of inflation). However, the recent CPI data and average hourly earnings data both point to an acceleration in price pressures. The focus is on how Powell frames the recent firming.

- UBS believes Powell will likely project increased confidence that inflation will rise to target this year.

- The Fed’s latest guidance (in its 31 January statement) states: “On a 12-month basis, both overall inflation and inflation for items other than food and energy have continued to run below 2 percent. Market-based measures of inflation compensation have increased in recent months but remain low; survey-based measures of longer-term inflation expectations are little changed, on balance.” Clearly this guidance is now stale in wake of recent developments.

PACE OF NORMALISATION:

- The insertion of the word “further” in the January statement has been interpreted as a hawkish signal that the Fed could hike rates more than forecast in December (in the December staff economic projections, the Fed pencilled in three hikes in 2018 – note, those December forecasts may be alluded to in the report, new forecasts are due in March).

- SGH Macro Advisers says a clear majority of the FOMC, including its new Chairman, will want the optionality on the table of a potential fourth rate hike this year. But SGH believes that Powell and most of his Committee colleagues will not want to signal the fourth rate move as a given in either the testimony.

- The Fed’s current guidance (in its 31 January statement) states: “The Committee expects that, with further gradual adjustments in the stance of monetary policy, economic activity will expand at a moderate pace and labor market conditions will remain strong” and “The Committee expects that economic conditions will evolve in a manner that will warrant further gradual increases in the federal funds rate; the federal funds rate is likely to remain, for some time, below levels that are expected to prevail in the longer run.”

MARKET VOLATILITY:

- The recent market volatility has been attributed to inflationary pressures forcing traders to reprice their expectations of the Fed hiking cycle. After the FOMC’s experience of the ‘taper tantrum’ in 2013, it will be cautious about managing market expectations.

- At his swearing-in ceremony Powell alluded to the recent market volatility, stating that the Fed will “remain alert” to any financial stability risks presented by market gyrations. Other FOMC members – Like Kaplan – have attributed the market moves as “healthy”

subject: Brazil's President Temer says will not seek reelection in October's election
Bank of America Merrill Lynch Weekly Flow Show: Risk-on flows, risk-off trades
content:
Highlights: 
- Risk-on flows: equities over bonds, tech, EM bonds/ equities
- Positioning: remains optimistic & vulnerable to stagflation hawks
- Risk-off trades: long USD, long vol, short credit, short tech, short EM

- Risk-on flows: $13.2bn into equities, $5.2bn into bonds, $0.4bn into gold
- Rotation flows: equity inflows have outpaced bond inflows past 18 months, 1st time since Great Rotation of 2013
- Deflation flows: yet higher growth/higher rates backdrop not reflected in other flows...inflows to deflationary winners of tech, IG bonds, EM bonds/equities continues
- BofAML Bull & Bear indicator: stuck @ 8.2 ...excess optimism continues on risk assets, thus pain trade for stocks & credit still to downside; note however EM flow trading rule "sell signal" triggered on Feb 1st now subsides back to neutral territory
- Here comes vol: lots of volatility events in coming weeks...Feb 28th Powell @ Humphrey-Hawkins, March 1st US ISM, March 4th Italian elections/Merkel coalition vote, March 8th ECB, March 9th BoJ & US payroll/wages, March 21st FOMC
- Stagflation hawks vs. Goldilocks doves: if as we suspect data stagflationary/ policy hawkish then another risk-off bout coming
- Risk-off trades: best trades to play further risk unwind in Q1; long US dollar, long volatility, short credit, short tech, short EM, i.e. further unwind of big 2018 consensus positions
- Inflection corroboration: recent 5 months of lower US dollar & higher US bond yields rare (<10% of past 50-year history, Table 1, though v common in Emerging Markets); has coincided with bouts of inflation and/or market volatility...on average inflation rose 2ppt, equities fell 9% and volatility rose 22ppt; higher wages remains the obvious risk to investors; higher wages & peak profits/growth much less anticipated

subject: General Mills (GIS) is said to buy Blue Buffalo (BUFF) for USD 40/shr, equating to approximately USD 8bln in cash
DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses enter the North American crossover lower after drifting to the downside ahead of the US entrance to market
content:
23rd February 2018

  • European bourses enter the North American crossover lower after drifting to the downside ahead of the US entrance to market
  • The DXY has slipped further below the 90.000 level, and it remains a very close call whether the Greenback can continue its recent ‘winning’ run
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI and a slew of speakers

 

ASIA

Asian equities closed the week on a positive note as major bourses traded in the green amid the uptick in crude prices. ASX 200 (+0.8%) had been buoyed by energy and material names, moving within closing just shy of 6,000. Miners were led by BHP (+1.5%) and South 32 (+5%), while oil prices rose throughout the US session after the latest DoE crude inventory data showed US oil output had dropped. Elsewhere, the Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) edged higher with the gains led by defensive stocks with investors seemingly content to shrug off the notion of a more aggressive Fed unwinding stimulus more rapidly than expected. Chinese markets had been positive for much of the session with the Hang Seng (+1%), while the Shanghai Comp (+0.6%) had a somewhat choppy session. JGB yields dipped overnight, with the curve modestly flatter.

Japanese CPI, Ex Food and Energy YY (Jan) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%)

Japanese CPI, Core Nationwide YY (Jan) 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.9%)

Japanese CPI, Overall Nationwide (Jan) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.0%); Highest since March 2015

China revises January trade surplus higher to USD 20.35bln vs. prelim USD 20.34bln, according to customs. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says President Trump's policies will boost wages without inflation concerns. (Newswires)

UK opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn could use a key Brexit speech on Monday to pave the way for Labour to inflict a Commons defeat on the government, by backing a rebel Tory amendment seeking to keep Britain in “a customs union”. (Guardian)

UK PM May and 11 senior ministers have been thrashing out the UK's approach to Brexit in an eight-hour discussion at the PM's country retreat. The PM will set out the position in a speech next week, after a discussion by the full cabinet. (BBC)

Sun political journalist: ''I'm told by a Cabinet source that the agreed Brexit blueprint is “an ambitious opening gambit”. In other words, little expectation the EU27 will accept it.'' (Twitter)

EU citizens who arrive in Britain during the post-Brexit transition period will be allowed to stay permanently under a U-turn planned by UK PM May. (Times)

EU Inflation Final MM (Jan) -0.9% vs. Exp. -0.9% (Prev. 0.4%)

EU Inflation, Final YY (Jan) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.3%)

EU Infl Ex Food & Energy MM (Jan) -1.3% vs. Exp. -1.6% (Prev. 0.4%)

EU Infl Ex Food & Energy YY (Jan) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.2%)

CENTAL BANKS

Riksbank Minutes: Several members expressed concerns about inflation developments in the future and stressed that the downside risks deserve particular attention when deciding at what time and at what rate it is appropriate to start raising the repo rate.

- Riksbank’s Floden claims inflation still is a source of worry despite being close to target

- Riksbank’s Skingsley says downward revision is of such size that believes Repo rate path could be postponed

- Riksbank's Jochnick notes the uncertainty factors could also be seen as arguments for postponing rate rises slightly

 

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) stated that the view of 3 rate hikes is appropriate and could change if employment and inflation exceeds his forecasts. (Newswires)

ECB's Smets says EUR strength is not yet a concern and has full confidence that the ECB will reach inflation target. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

European bourses are trading on the back foot (Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%) despite calls for a slightly firmer open. In terms of sector specific moves, telecoms are the clear outperformer with BT Group (BT/A LN) shares at the top of the FSTE 100 following a positive broker upgrade at Berenberg. However, the biggest story in the UK equity space comes from RBS (-4.5%) who are one of the notable laggards in the FSTE 100 as a return to profit for the Co. was not enough to soothe investor concerns over restructuring costs and a lack of clarity from the DoJ investigation. Other notable movers include Valeo (-9.5%), IAG (-4.7%), Swiss Re (+1.8%) and Pearson (+1.1%) post-earnings, while Standard Life Aberdeen (+2.2%) have been granted some reprieve after offloading their insurance unit to Phoenix (+5.4%).

FX

The DXY has slipped further below the 90.000 level, and it remains a very close call whether the Greenback can continue its recent ‘winning’ run to make it 5 out of 5 trading days and a first complete week of gains this year. Technically, the index needs to close above 90.500-600, so quite a bit above the upper end of the 90.060-89.750 range thus far, and much may depend on the overall tone that emerges from the latest round of Fed rhetoric via a slew of speakers and Powell’s first semi-annual monetary policy report. However, Usd/Jpy still looks pivotal for the Dollar’s overall direction with the pair now heavy around 107.00 having failed to rebound to 108.00 at the height of its rebound from 105.55 lows. Note also, a large 107.00 option expiry strike for next Monday (1.6 bn) may act like an anchor. Eur/Usd straddles 1.2300, with no reaction to final Eurozone CPI and Cable continues to be drawn towards 1.4000 while holding in above solid support ahead of 1.3800 on Brexit-related weakness (similarly 0.8800 is a pivot in Eur/Gbp). In terms of crosses, Eur/Sek has been a mover in wake of cautious and dovish Riksbank minutes as several Board members registered concerns about weak inflation at the January policy meeting, and the pair has eclipsed the 10.0333 peak from 2017, with the previous year’s high at 10.0833 next on the charts. Back to G10s, the Nzd gained little lasting traction from better NZ retail sales overnight, with a breakdown revealing discretionary items providing a major boost, and Aud/Nzd stop-buying also working against the Kiwi.

FIXED INCOME

Market observers cite stops triggered in Bunds around the 158.90 level on the way to and through 159.00, and the core Eurozone debt future extended to 159.23 before running out of steam for a 47 tick advance on the previous close. Gilts have followed suit, but continue to lag on more hawkish BoE vs ECB near term policy dynamics and remain capped ahead of 122.00, albeit just at 121.97 (+27 ticks on the day). The 10 year Eurozone benchmark is outperforming peripheral bonds with Italian paper carrying more political risk premium ahead of the March 4 election and with supply coming today. US Treasuries also ticking up in sympathy it seems, but also continuing the relief and consolidation rally amidst further flattening, as this week’s mega issuance is out of the way (at least in terms of the auction process) and the focus returns to Fed policy via a raft of speakers and the semi-annual MPR.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures have seen a mild pullback from yesterday’s post-DoE surge, albeit in close proximity to yesterday’s best levels. Energy newsflow remains light with traders awaiting today’s Baker Hughes release which has recently seen a trend of climbing rig counts. In metals markets, gold prices are marginally softer alongside the firmer USD and remains on track for its worst weekly performance since late last year. Elsewhere, Chinese steel futures staged a rebound overnight as traders eye a potential pick-up in demand next week as Chinese participants fully return to market.

GEOPOLITICAL

US is said to announce new sanctions on North Korea later today, according to sources. (Newswires)

Sells EUR 1.123ln 2028 with average yield of 0.89% (Prev. 0.97%), B/C 1.77 (Prev. 1.85)

subject: Nordea on the Riksbank Minutes: The Riksbank minutes were dovish and confirm that the Executive Board is split
content:
- The minutes confirm that the inflation remains the focal point and the board are concerned over the inflation outlook. The majority of the board seems hesitant to hike rates and it was a close call that the rate path was lowered in the February report.

- In all, the stage is set for a downward revision of the rate path at the April meeting and the following meetings. The minutes strengthen our view that the Riksbank will stay on hold this year.

subject: Morning EU Movers: Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) +3.3%, BT (BT/A LN) +2.6%, Shire (SHP LN) +2.3%, Swiss Re (SREN SW) +1.03%, IAG (IAG LN) -2%, SES (SESG FP) -2.2%, RBS (RBS LN) -3.6%
UK STIRs narrowly mixed, Gilts maybe betwixt and between
content: Very quiet start to Friday’s session for Short Sterling futures, although the front month March contract has seen relatively decent volume and seemingly selling interest a fraction below Thursday’s settlement level (99.345 currently, -0.5 tick) and suggesting an uptick in the 3 month Libor fix. UK debt may also return to Liffe close to unchanged on the day having closed at 121.70 yesterday given mixed external leads (Bunds firmer/USTs softer for choice), and with a blank domestic docket until midday when BoE’s Ramsden participates in a panel discussion. However, lots more potential for US inspired trade and price movement later today with a heavy Fed agenda including speakers and new Chair Powell’s semi annual MPR.

subject: Bunds: acknowledging upturn in risk sentiment, initially
content: A mildly softer Eurex open in line with a dip in US Treasury futures overnight amidst firmer Asian-Pac equities, but the 10 year German bond remains underpinned on pull-backs having rebounded firmly from sub-158.00 lows earlier this week, and after an initial print at 158.68 vs yesterday’s 158.76 close Bunds have already bounced to trade above parity. The core debt future is now retesting resistance around 158.85 and just hit 158.91, but needs more momentum to make a clean upside break and mount a serious challenge against the next bullish technical objectives (159.30-33 on some charts, assuming the psychological 159.00 level does not thwart buyers in the interim). More qualms about relative Eur strength raised by the ECB suggest no rush to speed up the pace of policy normalisation, and a similar message or tone could well be in the offing from Coeure later today as one of the dovish-leaning GC members. Data-wise, final Eurozone CPI is unlikely to be a major market-mover, but a raft of Fed speakers and new Chair Powell’s first semi-annual Monetary Policy Report will be pivotal.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Shire (SHP LN) – The FDA is expected to provide a decision on Lanadelumab by Aug. 26th 2018, based on the Prescription Drug User Fee Act. (Newswires)

RBS (RBS LN) – FY 2017 net interest income GBP 8.99bln vs. Exp. GBP 8.99bln, FY attributable profit GBP 752mln vs. Prev. loss of GBP 7bln. CET1 ratio 15.9%. GBP 765mln conduct and litigation charges in Q4. Provides no update on the timing of their settlement with the US DoJ. (Newswires)

IAG (IAG LN) – FY 2017 revenue EUR 20.3bln vs. Exp. EUR 23bln, operating profit EUR 3.02bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.05bln and FY net EUR 2.02bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.95bln. (Newswires)

Pearson (PSON LN) – FY 2017 Revenue GBP 4.51bln vs. Exp. GBP 4.57bln, adj. operating profit GBP 576mln vs. Exp. GBP 562.9mln and EPS GBP 0.541 vs. Exp. GBP 0.588. (Newswires)  

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – The Co.’s JV with Canal+ on content is no longer happening, according to press reports. (Newswires)

Repsol (REP SM) – Co. are set to initiate a share buyback program, according to reports. (Newswires)

SES (SESG FP) – FY revenue EUR 2.04bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.03bln. FY net profit attributable to shareholders EUR 596.1mln vs. Exp. EUR 472mln. FY EBITDA EUR 1.32bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.32bln. (Newswires)  

Aviva (AV/ LN) – Co. have announced the sale of its insurance/pensions JV for EUR 202mln. (Newswires)

Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) – Adj. profit before tax GBP 1.039bln vs. Prev. GBP 1.054bln. FY dividend +7.5% to GBP 0.213/shr. Total adj. operating income +4% to GBP 2.928bln vs. Prev. GBP 2.820bln. with fee revenue +3% to GBP 2.763bln. Co. confirmed sale of insurance unit to Phoenix (PHNX LN), total consideration of GBP 3.24bln. (Newswires)

William Hill (WMH LN) – FY net revenue GBP 1.7111bln vs. Prev. GBP 1.603bln. FY Adj. profit GBP 291.3mln vs. Prev. GBP 261.5mln, FY loss before interest and tax GBP 43.7mln vs. Prev. GBP 225.6mln and full-year dividend up 6% to GBP 0.13/shr. (Newswires)

Rightmove (RMV LN) – FY revenue GBP 243.3mln vs. Prev. GBP 220mln. FY underlying operating profit +11% to GBP 184.4mln. Final dividend GBP 0.36/shr. Positive outlook remains for UK online property advertising market. (Newswires)

BHP (BLT LN)/ Exxon (XOM) – The two companies reached a joint decision in abandoning the sale of their Australian oil fields after running a 20-month sale process. (Newswires)

Telefonica Deutschland (O2D GY) – Co. stated they expect a boost of EUR 600mln to OIBDA between 2019 and 2022. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include earnings from Swiss Re and news from Airbus and Telecom Italia
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

23rd February 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities look set to close the week on a positive note as major bourses traded in the green amid the uptick in crude prices. ASX 200 (+0.8%) had been buoyed by energy and material names, moving within closing just shy of 6,000. Miners were led by BHP (+1.5%) and South 32 (+5%), while oil prices rose throughout the US session after the latest DoE crude inventory data showed US oil output had dropped. Elsewhere, the Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) edged higher with the gains led by defensive stocks with investors seemingly content to shrug off the notion of a more aggressive Fed unwinding stimulus more rapidly than expected. Chinese markets had been positive for much of the session with the Hang Seng rising 0.8%, while the Shanghai Comp had a somewhat choppy session.

FTSE

Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) – Phoenix (PHNX LN) is said to be in talks to buy the co.’s insurance unit. Phoenix is said to be planning about a GBP 1bln capital increase for the deal. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BT (BT/A LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

BAE SYSTEMS (BA/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAX

Allianz (ALV GY) – EWE will put a minority stake worth USD 1.9bln on the block later this year. The sale is expected to draw interest from groups including Allianz Capital Partners. (Newswires)

Norwegian state fund wants to increase investments in Germany

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Rhoen-Klinikum (RHK GY) – FY 2017 prelim revenue EUR 1.21bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.21bln and EBITDA EUR 98mln vs. Exp. EUR 100mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

E.ON (EOAN GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) -  The co. is among 5 of the remaining bidders for Canada’s jet unit, it is among Boeing (BA NY), Dassault Systemes (DSY FP), Lockheed Martin (LMT NY) and Saab (SAAB SW)

Valeo (FR FP) - FY revenue 18.6bln vs Exp. EUR 18.7bln, Net profit EUR 1bln vs Exp. EUR 1bln. (Newswires)

Saint-Gobain (SGO FP) – FY revenue EUR 40.81bln vs. Exp. EUR 41bln, EBITDA EUR 4.23bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.3bln and operating income EUR 3.03bln vs. Ex. EUR 3bln. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

US

EQUITIES: SPX +0.1% at 2704, DJI +0.7% at 24961, NDX +0.4% at 6762

Top sectors: Energy +0.9%, Materials +0.6%, Industrials +0.4%

Bottom sectors: Financials -0.6%, Healthcare -0.25% Tech -0.16%

The EMINI S&P 500 March 2018 contract was jittery; in early trade, investors were content to shrug-off the notion of a more aggressive Fed potentially withdrawing stimulus more rapidly than anticipated – certainly more rapidly than the central bank had forecast in its December projections. There was no new narrative for today’s price action; once again, traders seem to be contending with the Fed at a time when some have been complaining about frothy valuations (for some time, it should be noted). There may have been some positioning-related elements keeping the bid in stocks: analysts at JPMorgan argued that their equity models suggest that systematic selling of US equities has significantly eased, and volatility-targeting strategies might now be building longs; the bank also said that next week’s month-end is likely to see substantial buying from fixed-weight allocators, meaning that equity flows could be “a headwind for any near-term bearish bias.” The EMINI managed to print highs just above 2730 in afternoon trade before running out of steam, and in late trade, the March 2018 contract dropped to re-test the 2700 level, and that level was breached heading into the close.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equities look set to close the week on a positive note as major bourses traded in the green
content:
• Asian equities look set to close the week on a positive note as major bourses traded in the green
  • EU citizens who arrive in Britain during the post-Brexit transition period will be allowed to stay permanently under a U-turn planned by UK PM May
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German GDP, Eurozone inflation, Riksbank minutes, Canadian CPI and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asian equities look set to close the week on a positive note as major bourses traded in the green amid the uptick in crude prices. ASX 200 (+0.8%) had been buoyed by energy and material names, moving within closing just shy of 6,000. Miners were led by BHP (+1.5%) and South 32 (+5%), while oil prices rose throughout the US session after the latest DoE crude inventory data showed US oil output had dropped. Elsewhere, the Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) edged higher with the gains led by defensive stocks with investors seemingly content to shrug off the notion of a more aggressive Fed unwinding stimulus more rapidly than expected. Chinese markets had been positive for much of the session with the Hang Seng rising 0.8%, while the Shanghai Comp had a somewhat choppy session. JGB yields dipped overnight, with the curve modestly flatter.

Japanese CPI, Ex Food and Energy YY (Jan) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%)

Japanese CPI, Core Nationwide YY (Jan) 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.9%)

Japanese CPI, Overall Nationwide (Jan) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.0%); Highest since March 2015

China revises January trade surplus higher to USD 20.35bln vs. prelim USD 20.34bln, according to customs. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU citizens who arrive in Britain during the post-Brexit transition period will be allowed to stay permanently under a U-turn planned by UK PM May. (Times)

UK PM May and 11 senior ministers have been thrashing out the UK's approach to Brexit in an eight-hour discussion at the PM's country retreat. The PM will set out the position in a speech next week, after a discussion by the full cabinet. (BBC)

UK opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn could use a key Brexit speech on Monday to pave the way for Labour to inflict a Commons defeat on the government, by backing a rebel Tory amendment seeking to keep Britain in “a customs union”. (Guardian)

ECB's Smets says EUR strength is not yet a concern and has full confidence that the ECB will reach inflation target. (Newswires)
 

FX

Across FX markets, price action had been relatively quiet for much of the session. Firmer than expected readings across the board for Japanese inflation data had been seemingly shrugged off by the JPY as inflation still remains far off the BoJ’s 2% target. Elsewhere, NZD underperformed overnight despite better than expected retail sales data for Q4, with analysts suggesting that this is not enough to change the narrative for the RBNZ as price pressures continue to remain subdued. Alongside this, cross related buying in AUD/NZD kept the NZD pressured as the cross moved above 1.07 and in turn push NZD through 0.73.


COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures fell slightly overnight, however prices did trade within close proximity to yesterday’s highs which had been led by yesterday’s DoE data, which showed a larger than expected drawdown, while US crude output also dipped. Elsewhere, in the precious metals complex, gold prices were pressured amid the risk on tone seen in Asia, while the USD index also picked up overnight.

Motiva Port Arthur Texas refinery (capacity 603k bpd) large crude unit is said to restart in early March, according to sources. (Newswires)

Phillips 66 alliance louisiana refinery (capacity 260k bpd) is preparing for reformer and hydrotreater overhauls in March, according to sources. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US is said to announce new sanctions on North Korea later today, according to sources. (Newswires)


US

TREASURIES: US T-Note futures settle 7 ticks higher at 120-12+

Treasury yields were a touch lower, and major curve spreads were mixed, on a day where the US Treasury’s $258bln of supply was complete (including bills), and a hefty slate of corporate supply, which saw heavy issuance in the 5-, 10- and 30-year buckets. As that supply was launching in afternoon trade, there was some pressure on the Tplex, though the curve remained in positive territory.

The US Treasury completed its supply with a lacklustre sale of 7-year notes on Thursday. The auction saw a tail of 0.7bps, cover was the lowest since November, and direct bidders took down their largest share since September. There was a little encouragement in the internals, after indirect participation didn’t mirror what we saw out of the 2s and 5s auction this week, where it was notably high. Treasury prices were little changed following the sale.

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) stated that the view of 3 rate hikes is appropriate and could change if employment and inflation exceeds his forecasts. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says President Trump's policies will boost wages without inflation concerns. (Newswires)

subject: Singapore CPI (Jan) Y/Y 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.54 (Prev. 0.4%)
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asian equities set to close out the week on the front foot as investors shrug off the notion of a more aggressive Fed
content:
Asian equities look set to close the week on a positive note as major bourses trade in the green. ASX 200 has been buoyed by energy and material names. Miners has been led by BHP and South 32, while oil prices rose throughout the US session after the latest DoE crude inventory data showed US oil output had dropped. Elsewhere, the Nikkei 225 edged higher with the gains led by defensive stocks, while investors seem content to shrug off the notion of a more aggressive Fed unwinding stimulus more rapidly than expected. Chinese markets have also confirmed to the positive tone, with the Shanghai Comp extending on yesterday stellar gains.

Across FX markets, price action has been relatively quiet, JPY seemingly unfazed by the higher than expected inflation data out of Japan. NZD dipped despite solid retail sales data which came ahead of analysts estimates. However, this is not enough to change the narrative for the RBNZ, while price pressures continue to remain subdued, alongside this, AUD/NZD has seen a break above 1.07 which in turn has pressured NZD to move towards the 0.73 handle.
